dcterms_description:
This module provides guidelines for undertaking a desktop study and then covers the procedures and guidelines for recording the survey methods, effort and outcomes of targeted surveys and monitoring for species or ecological communities. Targeted surveys do not need to occur at a plot, and where the project or research goals of individual projects dictate variation in survey or trap design, or use of methods not applied during plot-based surveys, the Targeted surveys module should be used. Targeted surveys should not be viewed as an alternative to standardised plot-based surveys and should generally be used in addition to plot-based surveys, to obtain further information about species or ecological communities.

The module contains three protocols:

  1. Fauna protocol – to record survey type, survey effort and any observations of target fauna species or suitable habitat within the project area.

  2. Flora protocol – to record survey effort and any observations of target flora species, populations or suitable habitat within the project area.

  3. Ecological community protocol – to record survey effort and any observations of target ecological communities within the project area.

This module has links to the following modules:

  • Vertebrate fauna – provides further details on vertebrate fauna survey, collection and vouchering methods. Fauna surveys can trigger the need for targeted surveys if a threatened species is identified at a plot.

  • Invertebrate fauna – provides further details on invertebrate fauna survey, collection and vouchering methods. Invertebrate fauna surveys can trigger the need for targeted surveys if a threatened or invasive species is identified at a plot.

  • Opportunistic observations – opportunistic observations of species of interest (e.g. threatened or invasive) may trigger the need for targeted surveys.

  • Floristics – provides further details on vascular plant collection and vouchering methods. Floristics surveys can trigger the need for targeted surveys if a threatened species is identified at a plot.

  • Plant vouchering – provides further details on vascular plant collection and vouchering methods.

  • Camera traps – provides further details on camera trap methods and set up. The point protocol in the Camera traps module can be used for targeted surveys.

  • Vegetation mapping - the results from the vegetation mapping module can be used to indicate potential habitat areas that may require a targeted survey and the presence of any TECs. If a threatened or invasive species is detected at a vegetation mapping point, this may trigger the need for a targeted survey.

  • Recruitment – the survivorship protocol in the Recruitment module can be used to track survival, growth and life-stages of individual plants overtime, and can be used to monitor target flora species.

Desktop study

One of the first steps when undertaking a targeted survey should always be to complete a desktop study or review, to gather contextual information on the area and species/community to be surveyed from existing surveys or reports, scientific literature, database searches and spatial information (see Appendices 1 and 2 for resources to assist with desktop studies). Desktop studies can help to plan and undertake field surveys (Environment Protection Authority 2020), and the information collated can be used to make informed decisions on the appropriate level of survey effort, key survey methods and techniques, stratification of the project area and can feed into background information for reporting. Desktop studies should involve a search for all relevant sources of literature, data and map-based information (Freeman et al. 2015, Environment Protection Authority 2020), and requires a thorough examination of the literature to identify the best times, locations and techniques for the survey (Department of Sustainability‚ Environment‚ Water‚ Population and Communities 2011a).

There are a range of sources that can be reviewed, including:

  • Databases maintained by the Australian Government, including the Species Profile and Threats (SPRAT) database and the Protected Matters Search Tool (see http://www.environment.gov.au/cgi-bin/sprat/public/sprat.pl and https://www.awe.gov.au/environment/epbc/protected-matters-search-tool).

  • State and Territory conservation agencies and local government databases and predictive models

  • National and State/Territory threatened species recovery plans and teams

  • Reference books, including field identification guides

  • Aerial photographs and satellite imagery, topographic maps, vegetation maps, geological maps and soils maps

  • Historic records and flora, fauna and vegetation communities

  • Lists of threatened species, populations or ecological communities in the area

  • Literature about the ecology of the species, communities and habitats found or likely to be found in the area

  • Consultation with local groups, researchers and experts (Department of the Environment 2013b).

All information used in a desktop study requires an evaluation of its reliability and suitability for the current project, including the source and age of the information, suitability of techniques used, skills and experience of observer/researcher, data analysis and survey timing (DEC 2004, Environment Protection Authority 2020).

When undertaking a desktop assessment, the following can be points can be used as a guide when planning, designing and undertaking surveys:

  • The number and location of species records, and dates of those records

  • The distribution of species, population and ecological communities

  • The location and extent of suitable habitats within the project area

  • Current threats to the species or ecological communities

  • Recommended time(s) of year to survey

  • Recommended time(s) of day to survey

  • Optimal survey conditions (rainfall, wind, temperature etc)

  • Length of survey (i.e., number of trap nights) and survey effort (number of traps, search area)

  • Best practice survey methods

  • Recommended equipment and use

  • Site access and logistics

  • Necessary skills and experience

  • Habitat and behaviour (fauna species)

  • Habitat requirements and phenology (flora species).

A key process to undertake when planning a field survey is stratification of the project area. Stratification involves breaking the project area into assessment units that are relatively homogeneous, and these units are then used to determine the location and number of sites that are needed to adequately survey the habitat types present across the project area (Eyre et al. 2018). Vegetation maps, aerial photographs, topographic maps, occurrence records and satellite imagery can be useful for stratification and determining locations for targeted searches (Department of Sustainability‚ Environment‚ Water‚ Population and Communities 2011a).

Habitat preferences of the target species or community should be considered during the site selection process, and it is common for survey effort to be higher in areas of suitable habitat (Environmental Protection Authority 2016a). However, targeting survey effort to strata with high probability of occupancy risks misinterpreting true patterns of occurrence, as survey designs that rely heavily on previous knowledge have the risk of becoming self-fulfilling prophecies, as they uncritically reinforce underlying assumptions (Cristescu et al. 2019). In addition, the habitat needs and behaviour of many threatened species are often poorly understood (Department of Environment and Conservation NSW 2004). Consequently, all potentially suitable habitats should be systematically searched for targeted species or ecological communities (Environmental Protection Authority 2016a), and exclusion of habitat should only be to areas where a species or community cannot exist (Cristescu et al. 2019).

Timing of surveys is also an important consideration when planning surveys. Careful consideration of the necessary lead time is required, as it may be necessary to survey at specific times of the year, depending on the ecology of the species in the subject area, or to undertake multiple surveys across the year or across years (Department of the Environment‚ Water‚ Heritage and the Arts 2010b). Many species will vary in detectability between seasons because of behavioural differences or variation in habitat conditions (Department of the Environment‚ Water‚ Heritage and the Arts 2010b).

Surveys should be undertaken when the target species and/or communities are most detectable and identifiable in the field, (i.e. for flora, during the relevant flowering/fruiting time for each species) (Environmental Protection Authority 2016a). For areas with multiple significant species, there may not be a single time of the year suitable to detect all species, and in these cases, multiple visits, each targeting different species or groups should be considered (Environment Protection Authority 2020). For example, many cryptic and rare plants are more detectable during flowering or seed set, and the timing of these can vary across the year (NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service and SMEC Australia 2001), while peak invertebrate activity often coincides with rainfall events, which are difficult to predict (EPA 2016b).

    • THE PMST allows users to draw a feature around an area of interest, explore what’s in the area and generate a report.

    • Three terms are used to indicate the likelihood of occurrence of a threatened species, species habitat ecological community or within the project area:

      • Known to occur

      • Likely to occur

      • May occur

  •

  • SPRAT - http://www.environment.gov.au/cgi-bin/sprat/public/sprat.pl

    • The SPRAT database is designed to provide information about species and ecological communities listed up the EPBC Act.

    • The database provides the following information about threatened species:

      • Appearance

      • Population and distribution

      • Habitat

      • Movements

      • Feeding

      • Reproduction

      • Taxonomic comments

    • SPRAT provides information about the distribution of TECs and where available links to approved conservation advice, recover plans, information sheets and threat abatement plans.

    • To date, profiles are not available for every threatened species and ecological community.

dcterms_description:
The Camera traps module covers three camera trapping protocols that can be undertaken depending on the purpose of your project:

  1. Fauna plot protocol – standardised deployment of Reconyx 2–5 white flash camera traps and accompanying bait stations in a fauna plot, either in conjunction with a vertebrate fauna survey (recommended) or stand alone.

  2. Array protocol – many camera traps (e.g. 20–30) deployed in a systematic array (e.g. grid, transect) to monitor fauna occupancy and density in the project area (via downstream capture-mark-recapture methods and random encounter models).

  3. Targeted protocol – remote cameras deliberately deployed at features of interest (e.g. suitable habitat, trail intersections, waterpoints, tree hollows, inflorescences) in the project area to maximise fauna detection, supplement species inventory, or record behaviour, with the option to capture video, orientate camera traps horizontally (i.e. downward-facing detection zone and field of view) to survey small mammals and reptiles, and use bait stations or lures.

The module covers pre-field survey tasks, including study design considerations and remote camera preparation to maximise species detection and identification whilst minimising false triggers, as well as post-field survey tasks, including data storage, processing, and analysis.

The Fauna plot protocol includes the procedures and guidelines for the standardised deployment and recovery or redeployment of camera traps in a fauna plot, including standards for camera make, model and settings, camera placement and orientation, site preparation, bait station installation, deployment period, and entering the data directly into the App. The protocol is based on the standard operating procedure for camera trapping developed by the Northern Territory Flora and Fauna Division (Gillespie et al. 2015), and Bush Heritage Australia’s camera trap guidelines (Bush Heritage Australia 2021). Both standardised methodologies were developed from extensive trialing of various camera trap survey designs and consultation with a range of expert practitioners, to optimise the effectiveness and consistency of camera traps for general vertebrate fauna surveys and monitoring. For a standardised protocol that covers the effective and consistent use and deployment of remote cameras as part of general vertebrate biodiversity surveys (Gillespie et al. 2015), the fauna plot protocol is the best approach.

The Array protocol includes the procedures and guidelines for deployment, recovery and redeployment of camera traps in an array within the project area, including locating camera trap points in an evenly spaced grid or at regular intervals along a transect, and then micrositing the exact camera trap point locations within the grid or transect to optimise fauna detections, and recording all associated data (e.g. camera trap make, model and settings, camera trap placement and orientation, focal point, target species if applicable, deployment period) in a standardised manner directly into the App. The protocol has been developed based on the Terrestrial Vertebrate (formerly Camera Trap) Monitoring Protocol (TEAM Network 2011b). This protocol was developed from the collective experience of many field biologists with experience using camera trap arrays to estimate the abundance of a range of terrestrial mammal and bird species. The sampling design was carefully specified to maximise the probability of detecting an adequate sample of terrestrial mammal and bird species. It was intended to monitor changes in the community of ground-dwelling, terrestrial vertebrates, but not to monitor the abundance of individuals species. The sampling design compromised between detecting species that range over large areas (>100 km2) and those with smaller home ranges (~1 km2). The camera trap array protocol outlined here differs in that it allows the flexibility to monitor the community or individual species. Surveyors can select the density and number of camera traps, and the deployment period based on the aims of their project, with this information recorded in a standarised manner among projects using the App.

If you wish to undertake a general survey of the fauna across a project or study area without altering the behaviour of that fauna, the Array protocol is the most effective approach. As this protocol can be used to sample a broad area simultaneously and uniformly it provides a better sample size than the other protocols, thereby enabling a more accurate indication of species abundance over the whole survey area. For this reason, an indicated absence (where a species is not detected) from a camera trap array sample is more likely to reflect a true absence (where a species is not present) than the other protocols. If resources are limited, establishing a transect through the most representative part of the survey area and placing camera traps at pre-determined intervals along that transect, might be the best approach. However, indicated absences obtained from transect samples cannot be reliably used as an indication of true absence. It is possible to combine grid and transect approaches (Molloy 2018).

The Targeted protocol includes the procedures and guidelines for the deployment, recovery and redeployment of camera traps at features of interest within the project area, including identifying features of interest, micro siting the exact camera trap point locations to optimize fauna detections, installing bait stations, and recording all associated data (e.g. camera trap make, model and settings, camera trap placement and orientation, focal point, target species if applicable, bait station details, deployment period) in a standardized manner directly into the App. The targeted protocol may be used in combination with the fauna plot protocol to supplement species inventory when undertaking fauna monitoring within a project area. The targeted protocol has been included in recognition that deliberately biased placement of camera traps at features of interest are a commonly used camera trapping sampling strategy (Meek et al. 2014a). Targeted camera trapping can also be undertaken as part of the Targeted surveys module and can be used in combination with a range of other targeted methods.

If you are monitoring the behaviour of fauna under a certain set of conditions, sampling fauna at a specific set of points for experimental purposes (e.g., to examine responses of fauna to differing vegetation or specific landscape parameters), or monitoring fauna at a place of activity or gathering point such as a trail intersection, water point or nest site, the Targeted protocol is the most effective approach. This protocol allows researchers and practitioners to monitor a large area with minimal resources and to answer specific research questions. However, this approach is highly susceptible to bias and provides a limited insight into the ecology of the greater landscape as a whole (Molloy 2018).

The data standards for all three protocols are based on the Camera Trap Metadata Standard developed by Forrester et al. (2016), an open data standard for storing and sharing camera trap data. The standard captures information necessary to share data between projects and offers a foundation for collecting the more detailed data needed for downstream analyses. The standard captures information about study design, the type of camera trap used, and the location and species names for all detections, among others, in a standardized manner. The standard is compatible with the Federal Geographic Data Committee, the Darwin Core, the Ecological Metadata Language, and the Audubon Core metadata standards to allow data to be easily cross referenced with existing data repositories, such as DataONE (Forrester et al. 2016).

The Camera traps module is linked to the following modules:

  • Plot selection and layout – the fauna plot protocol requires a fauna plot to be selected, established and laid out.

  • Vegetation mapping – Fauna habitats in the project area and fauna plot selection can be informed by the results of the Vegetation mapping module.

  • Vertebrate fauna – camera traps can be used in combination with a range of other vertebrate fauna survey methods (e.g. pitfall trapping).

  • Targeted surveys – camera traps can be recorded as part of targeted surveys and can be used in combination with a range of other targeted measures.

  • Interventions – camera traps can be used to detect distribution and population trends associated with interventions to conserve threatened species, as well as monitor vertebrate pest population control.

Pre-field survey tasks

Study design and planning considerations

For many camera trapping applications, such as surveying the distribution of species, estimating species abundance, or monitoring changes in these parameters through time, proper attention must be given to the study design, the make and model of the camera trap used, camera trap deployment, and what data is collected and how it will be analysed. Poorly designed surveys often result in data which cannot be used to answer the question of interest (Gillespie et al. 2015).

A clear and defined statement of the study objectives and why camera traps are the best survey tool to achieve these objectives is an important component of camera trapping studies, which can range from investigations of behaviour, species inventory and assessing abundance, as well as exploratory, where the data produced (e.g. an image of a new species, or a range extension for an existing species) provides important information to address particular scientific or management questions. The study design and methodology should align with the clearly defined objectives (Meek et al. 2014a).

This section includes two decision keys (Figure 1 and Figure 2) to ensure the appropriate use of camera traps and the three camera trapping protocols, as well as design and planning considerations for detection, camera trap make and model, the number and density of camera traps in an array, deployment period, the target species, use of attractants, and permits and ethics.

Detection

Like any fauna survey methodology, camera trap surveys must address common sources of sampling error to reliably assess animal populations, including imperfect detection – where individuals or species present within a sampling are not always detected. Camera trap surveys, which sample mobile species, must consider imperfect detection at the camera trap scale, where fauna passing through the relatively small camera trap detection zone fail to be detected, and at the study area scale, where fauna using the study area that the camera trap is assumed to sample fail to be detected (Figure) (Burton et al. 2015).

The probability of detection (i.e. the probability that a species will be detected during a survey if it is present within the study area; Gillespie et al. 2015) is affected by several factors at the camera trap scale, including camera trap specifications, deployment mode, animal body size and temperature, animal movement speed, behaviour and group size, ambient temperature and light, and vegetation and other obstructions, and at the study area scale, including animal density and movement, the size and selection of sampling units, the number and location of camera traps, the use of attractant, the deployment period, and analytical assumptions (Burton et al. 2015). Consideration of these factors (see below) and following the carefully planned camera trapping protocols are imperative to reduce detection bias in camera trap field data collection. However, researchers will need to consider analytical approaches to contend with imperfect detection when undertaking downstream analyses (e.g. capture-mark-recapture methods, random encounter models).

Camera trap selection

The make and model of the camera traps used in a survey have important consequences for species detectability and the interpretation and repeatability of results. There are numerous manufacturers (e.g. Reconyx, Pixcontroller, Buckeye, Cuddeback, Bushnell, Scoutguard) that typically have multiple camera trap models available to researchers and practitioners. These makes and models vary in their trigger speed, detection zone, sensor sensitivity, how they detect fauna (e.g. PIR or AIR sensors) and how they illuminate the scene at night (e.g. white or infrared flash), among others (Table 2). Websites such as TrailCamPro.com provide comparative performance statistics as well specifications for many popular models (Meek et al. 2014a). The camera trap features that should be evaluated when selecting a camera trap model are summarised in Table 2. Only a single model of camera trap should be used in a study because performance is likely to vary among models.

Recording the make and model (including the manufacturing year for models that are updated frequently but keep the same name) of the camera traps used in a study ensures repeatability of the methods and comparability of the results, both among projects and monitoring surveys within the same project. Data of the remaining camera trap features summarised in Table 2 should also be collected with the camera trap make, model and year as these features are not always apparent.

Choosing the right tool for the job is common sense, but there are many examples where a poor choice of camera trap negatively affects the outcome. For example, images captured with infrared flash are monochrome and of relatively low resolution compared to those taken with a white light flash. Remote cameras with infrared flash are therefore not well suited to surveys of species that may be difficult to identify accurately from poor-quality images, such as many small mammal species. The possibility that the species of interest might be disturbed by a white light flash or the noises made by cameras and subsequently avoid the camera is also an important consideration (Gillespie et al. 2015). Furthermore, studies of animal use (e.g. burrows, tree hollows) may be better carried out using camera traps with an AIR sensor, rather than a PIR sensor, and choosing a camera trap with a small detection zone and a slow trigger response may be unsuccessful in detecting small and fast-moving animals at close range (Meek et al. 2014a).

Reconyx Hyperfire camera traps are the most widely used camera trap for wildlife research (Meek et al. 2012; Meek et al. 2015; Meek 2018). Protocols that specify the use of Reconyx camera traps in Australia include the standard operating procedure for camera trapping in northern Australia developed by the Northern Territory Flora and Fauna Division (Gillespie et al. 2015), and Bush Heritage Australia’s camera trap guidelines (Bush Heritage Australia 2021). Both of these protocols use Reconyx HC550 or PC850 camera for data consistency and comparability. These models have similar specifications and setting options, as well as LED white flash capability, which importantly allows colour images to be captured during the day and night, and significantly improves species identification capability (Gillespie et al. 2015). Internationally, the Terrestrial Vertebrate (formerly Camera Trap) Monitoring Protocol requires the use of Reconyx camera traps, particularly the HC500 or PC800 models, depending on the site’s climate (PC800 models used in humid climates). This is due to their rapid response time, infrared flash, multi-fire capabilities and unique design for field conditions (TEAM Network 2011b).

Feature Summary
Sensor (PIR or AIR) Most camera traps have passive infrared (PIR) sensor, which detect a differential in temperature and motion between a subject and the background temperature. When ambient temperature falls within the body temperature range of most mammals (31.5–36.5° C), PIR camera traps can be unreliable. PIR sensors can also be triggered by the movement of pockets of hot air or by the motion of warm vegetation in the detection zone. This problem can be limited by avoiding pointing the camera trap directly to a background that is under sun incidence. Active infrared (AIR) sensors, which respond to a break in an infrared beam between two units spaced apart, are not widely used but may, for example, be suitable for studies of animal use of burrows or tree hollows.
Trigger speed A fundamental feature of camera traps, if not the critical feature. Fast trigger speeds are necessary to capture fast moving targets. Fast trigger speeds may be less necessary if using a bait station.
Flash type (white or infrared) Camera traps with white flash are critical to capture sharp and colour images at night as well as during the day. This is fundamental in studies that require individual recognition or for faunal inventories, as colour images improve species identification. Currently, classic Xenon white flashes produce sharper images than white LED flashes due to their greater power and flash duration that is short enough to freeze moving animals. Camera traps with infrared flash use arrays of LEDs that emit infrared light, mostly in the range of 700–1000 nm. The images captured are often in grey-scale or may have a reddish-pink tinge. Infrared flashes tend to be less obvious to fauna, use less energy and tend to have quicker trigger speeds than white flashes. Recently, no-glow (also called “black”) infrared flashes have been introduced to minimise the red glow emitted by standard infrared LEDs which is seen by animals. A limited number of PIR camera trap models (e.g. Spypoint, Bolymedia) have dual flashes (Xenon and infrared).
Detection zone Critical feature that varies widely among current models (15.8–324.1 m; Meek et al. 2012). Camera traps with a narrow detection zone (i.e. smaller than the field of view) usually have fast trigger speeds and will take the photo when the animal is well within the field of view. The detection zone can be increased to some extent by moving the camera trap further away from the target, which can compensate for slow trigger speeds.
Number of photos taken, recovery time, and video Capability to capture bursts of images in rapid sequence (i.e. fast recovery time) may be important for improved species identification (as chances of obtaining a good image within a burst will be increased), recording individuals within family groups and packs, and analysis of passing sequences to derive day range, which is a critical parameter in the Random Encounter Model (REM; Rowcliffe et al. 2008). At night, Xenon white flash cameras are not capable to take photo bursts or videos due to the recharge time of flash that can take ≥ 30 seconds, a limitation that is overcome by LED white flash camera traps. Rapid image sequences and video can be useful for behavioural studies or specific research needs. However, data handling is more time consuming, SD cards are filled quicker and power consumption is greater, hence videos are not recommended when photographs alone provide the data required.
PIR sensitivity Regulates the sensor responsiveness to the target by changing the heat sensitivity threshold. High sensitivity is generally better to detect small-sized animals. However, this will increase chance of false triggers caused by warm, moving vegetation.
Flash intensity A number of camera trap models allow flash intensity to be adjusted automatically to the distance to the subject. Some models enable the amount of light generated by the white flash to be adjusted for two to three distance settings. However, the flash of most models is programmed for maximum distance and illumination.
Power autonomy Studies in remote areas and/or with long deployment periods require high power autonomy. Camera traps with white flash generally consume more battery power then those with infrared flash. The three most common battery types used by camera traps are AA Lithium, Nickel Metal Hydride (NiMH) and Alkaline, which are discussed in the Batteries section. Despite the higher initial costs, rechargeable NiMH batteries are recommended as long as camera trap performances are not altered. A number of camera models (e.g. Spypoint, Bolymedia, Uway) mount an input jack for external batteries or small solar panels so higher capacity, lead-acid batteries can be used to prolong deployment.
Image resolution, sharpness and clarity Most camera traps capture medium-to-high resolution images and video. However, the sharpness and clarity of colour images, needed to identify individuals and species, are also critical features. For images captured at night, only those taken with a white Xenon flash are clear and sharp enough to identify naturally marked individuals. Image resolution and clarity is often critical when targeting small animals, especially where sympatric species coexist with similar morphological features.
Camera housing and sealing Housing, camouflage and water and insect proof qualities of camera traps extremely important, especially where extreme weather conditions are experienced (e.g. snow, rainfall and humidity). In addition, ability to protect cameras with metal cases and lock them is critical against theft and/or damage by large animals. Housing should allow easy attachment of the unit to the support or tree used and allow access to replace batteries and SD cards when attached to the support. Housing should ideally have a tripod stud on the rear and underside to attach mounting brackets.
Camera programming and setting Should be as simple as possible, to allow researchers and practitioners with varying degree of experience to set camera traps consistently and without errors. The option of programming the operation time, to avoid unnecessary images, may be useful for example when only nocturnal species are targeted. Setting camera traps to take an image at regular intervals in time (i.e. time lapse), either at pre-designated intervals or regular intervals following a motion detection, may be useful to decrease data load while confirming presence or examine temporal activity of invertebrates (Williams et al. 2011; Potter et al. 2021).

Target species

The target species, suites of species, or community of interest should be clearly identified when planning camera trap surveys. This is because the study design, camera trap model, camera trap point selection, mode of deployment, deployment period and type and variety of lure, if used, should be tailored to the target fauna to maximise detection probability (Harmsen et al. 2010; Rovero et al. 2013; Diete et al. 2016; Fancourt et al. 2018; Moore et al. 2020a), with consideration of their size, behaviour and mode of body temperature regulation. For example, to maximise numbat (500–700 g mammal) detection, Swift 3C wide-angle camera traps set 25 cm above the ground are recommended as they recorded 89% of known events, compared to Swift 3C standard (51%) and Reconyx PC900 camera traps (37%). Furthermore, camera traps mounted at 2 m above the ground and angled towards the ground resulted in significantly more identifications of individual numbats than those mounted at 1 m and 1.25 m (Seidlitz et al. 2020). If using camera traps to survey small mammals, models with white flash will likely be required to capture the characteristic features required to distinguish similar-looking sympatric species with an acceptable level of precision (Meek and Vernes 2015). Video has also been crucial to distinguish two antechinus species, with their behaviour and movements being particularly diagnostic (Gray et al. 2017).

Tracks and roads have been shown to facilitate movement of introduced predators such as feral cats and foxes (Carter et al. 2012), and consequently, placing camera traps along them will increase the probability of detection (Meek 2018). Indeed, on-road detectability using camera traps was estimated to be seven times higher for cats and three times higher for foxes than off-road detectability. Furthermore, targeting camera trap survey effort on-road yielded the greatest power for detecting declines in both species (Geyle et al. 2020), which is useful for monitoring the success of lethal baiting programs.

The majority of camera traps work by sensing objects that move and are a different temperature relative to the background surface and objects. They are therefore most suited to detecting mammals and to a lesser extent birds (i.e. endotherms; TEAM Network 2011b; Cloyed et al. 2018), but are generally less sensitive at detecting reptiles and amphibians (i.e. ectotherms; Gillespie et al. 2015). However, camera traps positioned facing downwards have successfully monitored reptiles using bait stations to attract species to the detection zone, drift fences to direct species towards the detection zone, and cork tiles to create a sufficient thermal contrast between the tile, which is heated by the sun, and the species (Welbourne et al. 2015; Moore et al. 2020a). More recently, this approach was refined by reducing the focal length of Reconxy camera traps to avoid blurry images of when placing them facing downwards, 70 cm above the ground, This allowed small, similar looking sympatric species to be differentiated (Welbourne et al. 2019). Reconyx can alter the focal length of their professional series of camera traps at the time of purchase, but it is also possible for practitioners to adjust this themselves, as demonstrated by Welbourne et al. (2019).

For amphibians, camera traps set to capture time lapse images, or a combination of sensor triggered and time lapse images have been successfully used to monitor movements (Pagnucco et al. 2011), and describe activity patterns and behaviour (Hoffman et al. 2010; Engbrecht and Lannoo 2012), including for a rare and elusive micro-endemic frog species strictly dependent on bromeliads (Barata et al. 2018).

Ultimately, the target animals influence several study design considerations of camera trap surveys, meaning suitable ecological research is critical to a well-designed study (Meek et al. 2012). If possible, rigorous, species-specific testing should be undertaken to complement the use of well-regarded camera trap models and general deployment recommendations (Seidlitz et al. 2020).

Camera trap point selection and preparation

When choosing the exact location for a camera trap point, careful attention to where the camera trap is located and to site preparation can improve detection, facilitate species identification and significantly reduce the incidences of false triggers. On approaching the camera trap point, look for a suitable place to set the camera trap (Gillespie et al. 2015). Look for signs of fauna (e.g. tracks, scats) and features with a good chance of animal visitation (e.g. animal trails, creek banks, dry creek beds, narrow gullies, edges of dense vegetation, paths to water). Consider the target species or suite of species and their travel habits, the likely path of travel, the sensor’s range and field of view, and the terrain. Select the location that is likely to detect your target species or yield the greatest number of images of a suite of species, depending on the aims of your project (TEAM Network 2011b).

An ideal location is a flat or gently sloping area that is relatively clear of shrubs and ground vegetation, but is shaded by trees or rock over-hangs. If deploying camera traps in a rocky or densely vegetated habitat, think carefully how fauna might access the point; if access is limited then this will influence the detection probability (Gillespie et al. 2015).

Set the ‘stage’ for the camera trap. Occasionally, terrain or vegetation can obstruct the detection zone. Remove vegetation as needed, considering windy conditions, to maximise detection within the field of view of the camera trap and minimise false triggers. Try to keep the stage as natural as possible, taking care not to disturb the area too much or create obstructions of cleared vegetation (TEAM Network 2011b).

If using bait stations, it may be best to remove all vegetation around the bait station to ensure an uninterrupted view of fauna inspecting the bait and prevent false triggers. The vegetation around the base of the camera trap mount or tree to which the camera trap is attached to minimise the risk of fire damage to camera traps (Gillespie et al. 2015).

Mode of deployment

How a camera trap is deployed in the field (i.e. its height, angle, direction) can greatly improve detection probability and reduce false triggers. The detection zone of the PIR sensor in most camera traps is a wedge-shaped, horizontal band (or bands) spreading outwards from the front of the sensor. As a result, the detection zone increases in size with increasing distance from the sensor. Setting camera traps so that the sensor is at different heights above the ground and at different distances from the target area (e.g. a bait station) allows different sized fauna species to be targeted. Setting camera traps close to the ground (i.e. 15–20 cm), or higher and angled so that they point towards the ground, will record the greatest size range of animals, as sensors will be triggered by both smaller animals and the legs of larger animals. The camera trap’s field of view is more expansive vertically and generally wider than the sensor’s detection zone, so although only the legs of an animal may trigger the sensor the photograph will contain more of the animal. Detection zone area varies widely among camera trap models (see Meek et al. 2012). Camera traps with a narrow detection zone (i.e. smaller than the camera field of view) have usually fast trigger speeds and will take the photo when the animal is well within the field of view (Gillespie et al. 2015).

When targeting large animals, such as kangaroos, camera traps should be set so that the sensor is at the height of the animal’s shoulder (e.g. approximately 1 m above the ground). This will reduce the number of images of smaller non-target species, as these animals will be underneath the detection zone (Figure 4). A maximum distance of 5 m between the camera trap and the target area (e.g. a trail along which an animal may be walking) should allow adequate illumination and reduce the likelihood of animals being obscured by vegetation (Gillespie et al. 2015).

For medium-sized animals (e.g. quolls, bandicoots, possums), the camera trap should be set so that the sensor is approximately 50 cm above the ground (Figure 4). A distance of 3 m between the camera and the target area (e.g. bait station) will ensure the animal is in the foreground of the photograph and is clearly illuminated by the flash (Gillespie et al. 2015). For example, for bandicoots, camera traps are deployed approximately 50 cm above ground level in locations with evidence of recent diggings or suitable habitat, with inaccessible bait stations with rolled oats, honey and peanut butter (5:1:2 ratio; truffle oil optional at 20 ml/kg) bait attractant set up 1–3 m in front of each camera trap. Vegetation is removed to ground level between the camera trap and bait station and within 1 m around the bait station if necessary (Department of Sustainability‚ Environment‚ Water‚ Population and Communities 2011).

For small mammals, studies have found that a sensor height of approximately 20–30 cm above the ground, or downward facing camera traps increase detection (Welbourne et al. 2015; Gray et al. 2017; Dundas et al. 2019; Seidlitz et al. 2020). When targeting small mammals set the remote camera close to the target area (e.g. 1.5 m between the camera and bait station). Although small mammals are detected by remote cameras targeting medium-sized mammals, setting the camera close to the target area will capture the fine detail required for identifying certain small mammal species (Gillespie et al. 2015).

Setting camera traps to optimise detection of a wide range of species requires a balanced approach; there is no one size fits all. One option is to maximise the sensor sensitivity and the picture frame; set the camera up so that it is angled down towards a feature or bait station such that the field of view covers an area of ground from the foreground of the feature or bait station within 1.5 m of the camera trap to several metres beyond the feature or bait station. For single camera deployments, the bait station to camera distance should be 2.5 m. However, by deploying multiple cameras at a site, variable setups can also be incorporated, such as varying the bait station distance from 1.5 – 2.5 m (Gillespie et al. 2015).

For predators including cats, foxes and dogs, camera traps should be placed 30 cm from a road or track edge, 50 cm above the ground, set parallel to the ground (although this may vary depending on topography), oriented 23° to the road or track and facing away from the sun’s path, facing south and in shade is optimal. The detection point should be 4–6 m from the camera trap in the middle of the road or track. Rock outcrops, reflective surfaces and shadows in the field of view should be avoided, as well as vegetation close enough that it can blow into the field of view (Meek 2018).

Camera traps should be set so that they are facing south to prevent false triggers from sun glare and shadowing, and minimise sun damage to the camera lens and sensor. Avoid deploying with east and west-facing orientations to reduce false triggers from the rising and setting of the sun. If using a tree to mount a camera trap, select a solid tree that will not move in the wind (diameter greater than 20 cm), with a relatively straight trunk and with a clear area to the south to direct the camera trap (Gillespie et al. 2015).

Camera trap settings

Three adjustable settings are common to many remote camera traps that can be used to ensure animals are captured, false triggers are minimized, and camera traps remain operational for the duration of a deployment: (i) motion sensor sensitivity; (ii) activation time; and (iii) camera delay (Gillespie et al. 2015).

Adjusting the sensitivity of the PIR sensor changes the sensor responsiveness by changing the heat sensitivity threshold, therefore being responsive to the temperature differential between an animal and the background environment required to trigger the camera. Because this heat difference is larger in cold temperatures, PIR sensors are more sensitive in temperate environments or during cooler seasons. High sensitivity is typically better to detect small-sized mammals. Reducing the sensitivity may also help avoid the problem of false triggers during the day due to heated vegetation, passing shadows or heated ground. However, by reducing the sensitivity there is a risk that some animals may not trigger the camera, especially in warm environments experienced in many parts of northern Australia where there is less difference between an animal’s body temperature and that of its surroundings. For cameras with SD cards that have the capacity to retain large numbers of images on a single set of batteries, large numbers of false triggers are less problematic and the maximum sensitivity setting is recommended to avoid missing animals (Gillespie et al. 2015). However, the data storage and processing implications of this need to be considered.

Activation time settings allow camera traps to be set to operate continuously, only at night, or only during the day. Some camera traps can also be programmed to operate between particular times (e.g., 0500–0800 hours). When targeting species that are strictly nocturnal, setting the camera trap for night operation only will eliminate many false trigger events during the day and reduce the number of images of non-target species. Reliable knowledge of the activity patterns of the target species and testing of cameras to determine the level of light required will aid in determining whether this is an appropriate setting for nocturnal animals that may also be active at dawn and dusk (Gillespie et al. 2015).

Many camera traps include a feature that allows for a pause (e.g., 15, 30 seconds, 1 minute, 5 minutes) between successive triggers. This will reduce the number of photographs taken of the same animal (e.g., if animals linger for long periods at bait stations) and may be useful in areas where there are very high levels of animal activity, especially of non-target species (e.g., where macropods are common). The appropriate length of the delay will depend largely on the target species; a minimal delay will maximize the chances of obtaining multiple photographs of rare or cryptic species, while a longer delay would be appropriate when targeting slower moving animals that may travel in groups, such as macropods or feral herbivores (Gillespie et al. 2015).

Trigger speed (i.e., the speed with which a camera trap captures an image relative to when the sensor detects the animal) can be adjusted in some camera trap models. If available, this function can be useful for optimising detection of different species that may move through the field of view at different speeds, without the need for purchasing different camera trap models with different trigger speeds. Multiple trigger options in some camera traps, such as Reconyx, allow programming of camera traps to capture several images in quick succession each time the camera trap is triggered. This capability increases the likelihood of multiple images of the same animal, aiding in accurate species identification. The flash range is adjustable in some camera traps via the shutter speed setting (e.g., Reconyx). A slow shutter increases the flash range but also increases the potential for a blurry image. A fast shutter reduces flash range but results in a cleaner image. For smaller and faster moving animals, a faster shutter is recommended (Gillespie et al. 2015).

Time lapse settings allow programming the camera trap to take photos at predetermined time intervals, without being triggered. This function may be useful for recording the presence of species that do not readily trigger infra-red sensors, such as amphibians and invertebrates (Hoffman et al. 2010; Pagnucco et al. 2011; Engbrecht and Lannoo 2012; Barata et al. 2018; Potter et al. 2021), or for monitoring ecological processes, such as plant phenology (Kim et al. 2021). Some camera traps can also be set to capture video when they are triggered, which may be useful in behavioural studies (Hoffman et al. 2010; Krauss et al. 2018), distinguishing sympatric species (Gray et al. 2017), or individual identification in mark-recapture studies (Mattioli et al. 2018).

Attractant

Camera trap surveys often use lures to attract fauna into the detection zone of camera traps, thereby maximising the likelihood of detection. This is particularly important when targeting wide ranging species that occur at low densities and that do not use predictable travel routes or habitats where camera traps can be deployed. Without the attractive effects of a lure, the likelihood that such species will happen to pass by the camera trap and be detected may be very low (Gillespie et al. 2015). However, when using systematic camera trap arrays in surveys of occupancy and relative abundance, which rely on assumptions of equal detectability (Burton et al. 2015), lures should not be used to attract fauna to the camera trap points (TEAM Network 2011b; Meek 2018).

Lures can be edible (i.e. baits which may also have an attractive scent), olfactory (i.e. scent), auditory (i.e. sound) or visual. Common lures used to attract feral cats include baits (fresh chicken coated with fish oil), auditory lures (Feline Audio Phonic, Westcare Industries, Perth, WA, Australia), and scent lures (Catastrophic, a proprietary product developed by Outfoxed Pest Control, Melbourne, VIC, Australia) (Stokeld et al. 2015). Visual attractants, consisting of a white and pink feathers and a shiny compact disk to appeal to cat hunting instincts and increase the ability of a cat to detect the lure station, are often used in association with other types of lures (Bengsen et al. 2011). Stokeld et al. (2015) found no evidence that feral cats in northern Australia are more attracted to any of these specific bait types.

When using baits, the choice of bait depends on the food preferences of the species being targeted. When targeting carnivores, meat baits have generally been used in Australia, including chunks of raw chicken, kangaroo, rabbit or fish (e.g. pilchards, tuna log, perforated tins of cat food) and fish oil. However, meat and fish can putrefy very quickly, which may in fact act as a deterrent to some species. A standard mammal trapping bait mix of peanut butter, rolled oats and honey has been successfully used in surveys targeting a wide variety of small- and medium-sized native mammals, such as quolls, bandicoots, possums and rodents (Gillespie et al. 2015). A number of manufactured, lethal baits are commercially available for vertebrate pest management (e.g. FOXOFF®, FOXECUTE®, DOGABAIT®, CUROSITY®, Animal Control Technologies (Australia), Somerton, VIC, Australia), and these may serve as lures for camera trap studies targeting these species.

Placing baits and olfactory lures inside containers that allow airflow (e.g. small cages, tea infusers, perforated PVC pipes) suspended above the ground will protect them from removal by target and non-target species, and ensure that their attractiveness persists for as long as possible. Species including corvids, rodents, dingoes, and ants can interfere severely with baits. Attaching the bait container to a pole (e.g. star picket, wooden stake) secures it and provides greater flexibility in positioning of the bait in relation to the camera trap. Ants can be deterred by spreading dust or granular insecticide for ants around the base of the pole (Gillespie et al. 2015).

The NT Flora and Fauna Division has devised a bait container that is suitable for most baits and deployments and can be quickly constructed from readily available materials. The bait container is constructed using a short (80 mm) length of 50 mm PVC pipe with a wire-mesh ventilated end cap, an overhanging cover on the top and slit-ventilated bottom cap. The plumbing descriptions for the end caps are ‘vent water/insect proof PVC 50 mm’ for the top and ‘vent insect proof PVC 50 mm’ for the bottom (Gillespie et al. 2015).

Number and density of cameras

The number of camera trap points, whether single or multiple camera traps are allocated per camera trap point, the distance between camera trap points, the spatial coverage of a sampling unit, and the total survey area are all important considerations for camera trapping studies. An adequate number of camera trap points is required to ensure the sampling effort can reliably detect an effect relative to the total survey area. When determining this number, the desired levels of accuracy and precision must be considered relative to other influential factors, such as the increasing cost of deployment with each camera trap and the heterogeneity of the study area (Meek et al. 2014a). Table 3 outlines a rough guide to the minimum number of camera trap points with a single camera trap for occupancy surveys based on how common or rare and detectable a species is (Gillespie et al. 2015).

The daily detection probability of the camera traps and the number of repeat surveys that are carried out at each camera trap point (i.e. the number of camera trap nights) should also be considered when determining the number of camera trap points. In general, surveying more camera trap points a greater number of times using the camera trap settings and deployment mode with the highest probability of detection, will maximise the precision of the estimate of the rate of occupancy. However, there are usually conflicts and trade-offs between these three aims. For example, if limited numbers of camera traps are available for use on a particular project, then carrying out many days of survey at each camera trap point will limit the total number of points which can be surveyed over the course of a survey season. The expected precision associated with a particular sampling program can be calculated if reasonable estimates regarding the occupancy rate amongst the sampled camera trap points and probability of detection are available prior to the survey. This information may be available from a previous study of the same species, from pilot studies, or from expert opinion (Gillespie et al. 2015).

The distance between camera trap points, or camera trap spacing, will vary depending on the ecology of the target species and needs to be properly scaled to suitably sample the target species and ensure the independence of observations at adjacent camera trap points. The home ranges of target species should be considered and reported. More widely spaced camera traps will be appropriate for wide-ranging animals with large home ranges, while closer spacing is generally more suitable for species with smaller home ranges (Gillespie et al. 2015). Where camera trap points are in a regular grid or transect, as in the array protocol, distance between cameras can be recorded as a single value. However, where camera trap points are randomly or irregularly located, as in the targeted protocol, the average, minimum and maximum distance among the points along with a measure of the distribution of distances (e.g. standard deviation) should be recorded. For the latter, the survey area can be defined by calculating the areas enclosed by either the concave or convex perimeter of camera trap points (Meek et al. 2014a).

Where multiple species are being surveyed, detection bias needs to be considered as it is difficult to achieve an optimal camera trap spacing for a suite of species, and you are likely to end up with increased detection probability for some species and decreased detection probability for others (Harmsen et al. 2010; Foster and Harmsen 2012; Mann et al. 2015). Studies assessing the species richness of terrestrial mammals vary considerably in camera trap spacing, including <1 km (Trolle and Kéry 2005; Di Bitetti et al. 2014; Colyn et al. 2018), 1 km (Colyn et al. 2018), 1.5 km (Silveira et al. 2003), 2 km (Tobler et al. 2008; Colyn et al. 2018) and varied spacing between 1.75 and >5 km within the same study area (Srbek-Araujo and Chiarello 2013). Arrays of 20–30 camera traps at a density of one camera trap per 2 km2 are used to monitor changes in the community of ground-dwelling, terrestrial vertebrates in tropical regions (TEAM Network 2011b), whereas a robust predator monitoring program will often have at least 20–30 camera traps spaced approximately 1 km apart (Meek 2018).

Deploying more than one camera trap at each sampling location, as in the fauna plot protocol, will usually be expected to lead to an increase in the probability of detecting a species (Gillespie et al. 2015). Deploying multiple camera traps per camera trap point in an array may also be useful to determine occupancy, detectability and power to monitor population change of species among micro-habitats (e.g. monitoring feral cats and foxes on- and off-road; Geyle et al. 2020), or to assess the influence of camera trap placement relative to a grid point based on the number and type of animal signs (Colyn et al. 2018).

Deployment period

The deployment period of camera traps determines how many daily replicate samples are collected (Meek et al. 2014a), with datasets improving with increasing deployment periods (Kays et al 2009). This variable has been found to be a more important factor than camera trap spacing and microsite placement at grid points in providing accurate species richness estimates (Colyn et al. 2018). Ultimately, the optimal deployment time will depend on your target species, meaning further research should be undertaken to adequately prepare for your survey (Meek et al. 2012).

A common camera trap deployment period is 2–4 weeks (Kays et al. 2011). However, how common or rare a species is in the landscape and the detection probability will affect decisions around the deployment period of camera traps (Gillespie et al. 2015). In some cases, including where the number of camera trap points sampled is more important for analysis than deployment period (Kays et al. 2011), or during a pilot study to confirm that traps can adequately detect certain species and allow accurate identification (Meek and Vernes 2015), camera traps may be deployed for less than 2 weeks. However, the minimum recommended deployment period of camera traps to monitor small- and medium-sized mammals in Australia is 14 nights (Paull et al. 2011). A deployment period of 30 nights for each of 20–30 camera traps is used to monitor changes in the community of ground-dwelling, terrestrial vertebrates in tropical regions (TEAM Network 2011b). Similarly, camera traps are recommended to be deployed for a minimum period of four weeks to monitor predators (Meek 2018).

Storage and transport

Camera traps should be stored in a safe location and transported in sealed, padded containers to prevent accidental damage, water damage, dust damage and theft (Gillespie et al. 2015). When packing the camera traps to take in the field do not store them with food or any other substances that might leave an odour on the camera trap. Food or other scents might attract fauna to the camera trap in the field, biasing the estimates of detection probability. Do not carry camera traps and food in the same bag when walking to camera trap points. An open backpack frame to which the camera traps can be strapped is a practical solution to carry camera traps in the field (TEAM Network 2011b).

Permits and ethics

A key feature of remote cameras, in contrast to many other wildlife survey techniques, is that they are relatively non-invasive; animals don’t need to be physically captured or handled as part of the survey. From an ethical and animal welfare point of view, remote camera surveys are only minimally intrusive, with impacts on animals limited to minor disturbance caused by flashes and camera noise, and behavioural responses to baits and minor habitat disturbance. For these reasons, animal ethics approvals may still be required for implementing remote camera surveys (Gillespie et al. 2015).

You should contact the relevant animal ethics committee to ensure you have the required animal ethics approvals well in advance of your field survey. You will need to consider how often the animal ethics committee meets and the timeframe for approvals to be granted. It is also wise to allow time to address any queries from the committee or conditions that must be met prior to an approval being granted.

Camera trap preparation and calibration

The Camera traps module depends on the camera traps being in proper functioning order, so taking adequate care and maintenance of the camera traps essential. To ensure the highest possible quality and integrity of the data, close attention must be paid to preparing and calibrating the camera traps before they are deployed in the field. Preparations should be started no later than 1 week before a field survey (TEAM Network 2011b).

Camera trap identification

Before camera traps are deployed in the field they need to be allocated and marked with an identification number. Camera traps should also be registered in an equipment management database to keep track of their location (e.g. in storage, assigned to project RLP001), current firmware, and operational status (e.g. functional, damaged; TEAM Network 2011b).

  1. Clearly mark each camera trap externally with a unique identification number (e.g. 01, 02, 03) using a permanent, water resistant marker.

  2. Retrieve the serial number of each camera trap from the white sticker underneath the control panel.

  3. Record the Camera trap number and Serial number of each camera trap in an equipment management database (e.g. spreadsheet). Other data you may wish to record includes the camera trap Make, Model, Purchasedate, Firmware, Operationalstatus and Current location.

Camera trap manufacturers regularly provide firmware updates for their camera traps. Ensure you check the relevant website for updates and instructions for updating before each field survey or camera trap redeployment. As an example, the steps to update the firmware on Reconyx camera traps, which are used in the Fauna plot protocol, are provided below (Bush Heritage Australia 2021).

SD cards

SD card selection

A Secure Digital® (SD) card is required to store the images and video your camera trap captures. SD cards have various storage capacities and reading and writing speeds. Larger capacity cards are capable of storing more images and video. Several factors will influence your required storage capacity, including deployment period, target species, site conditions, selected image quality and whether you are capturing video. Most users find that 4GB or 8GB cards are more than adequate for general use, with capacity to store between approximately 4,000 and 8,000 3.1MP images, respectively. You may want to consider a larger storage capacity if camera traps are being deployed for a long period, the risk of false triggers is high, or you are capturing video. Ensure you check the maximum capacity SD card that your camera traps will accept.

SD cards with higher speed ratings are capable of reading and writing images faster, which is particularly advantageous when capturing RapidFire image sequences. Speed Class 10 SD cards, which are capable of high reading and writing speeds with a minimum write speed of 10MB/s, are recommend. It is also recommended that you purchase two SD cards per camera trap, so they can be easily swapped when redeploying camera traps.

SD card identification

Before SD cards are used in camera traps that are deployed in the field, they need to be allocated and marked with an identification number. Similar to camera traps, SD cards should also be registered in an equipment management database to keep track of their location (e.g. in storage, assigned to project RLP001, assigned to camera 01), (e.g. functional, damaged; TEAM Network 2011b).

  1. Clearly mark each SD card externally with a unique identification number (e.g. 01, 02, 03) using a permanent, water resistant marker.

  1. Retrieve the serial number of each SD card from the back of the SD card.

  2. Record the SD card number and Serial number of each SD card in an equipment management database (e.g. spreadsheet). Other data you may wish to record includes the SD card Brand, Type (SD, SDHC, SDHX), Purchasedate, Storage capacity, Format (e.g. FAT32), Format date, and Current location.

SD card formatting

Formatting an SD card effectively erases all the card data, giving you a fresh, empty folder structure to work with. After you have backed up your SD card after each field survey, you should format each SD card before the next field survey. This will ensure data from different surveys is not mixed up. Furthermore, regular formatting of SD cards can lower the risk of corrupt files.

  1. Ensure your data from the previous field survey is backed up.

  2. Insert your SD card into your computer’s SD card reader (or use an external SD card reader).

  3. For Windows, you should see your SD card under the list of available drives. Right-click on the drive and select ‘Format’. Under ‘File system’ select ‘FAT32’ if the SD card is 32 GB or smaller. If the SD card is 64 GB or greater, select ‘ExFAT’ then click on ‘Start’. Select ‘OK’ to ignore the warning that the data on the drive will be erased and begin formatting the SD card.

  4. For Mac, open Disk Utility and select the SD card on the left side of the window. Click on the ‘ERASE’ tab and then click on the ‘Format’ drop-down menu. Select ‘MS-DOS (FAT)’ if the SD card is 32 GB or smaller. If the SD card is 64 GB or greater, select ‘ExFAT’. Click ‘Erase’. Your Mac will delete the contents of your SD card and format it.

  5. Record the SD card Format and Format date of each SD card in an equipment management database (e.g. spreadsheet; see SD card identification).

  6. Insert a formatted SD card into each camera trap so they are ready for the survey.

Batteries

Each camera trap can require up 12 AA batteries depending on the make and model. Batteries should be selected after consulting the user manual of the camera traps you are using and consideration of your study requirements. The three most common battery types used are Nickel-Metal Hydride (NiMH), lithium and alkaline. Longer lasting batteries such as rechargeable NiMH and lithium batteries are preferred over alkaline batteries (TEAM Network 2011b), which tend to discharge quicker and also suffer in extreme cold weather (Meek et al. 2012).

Rechargeable and lithium batteries have similar upfront costs (excluding chargers). However, rechargeable batteries are a better long-term option and recommended for their reliability, longevity, and sustainability. In Australia, Eneloop and Eneloop Pro batteries are good quality and have been recommended by experts (Meek et al. 2012). It is common practice to have two complete sets of rechargeable batteries per camera trap, which enables the seamless redeployment of camera traps within and between studies. Instructions for preparing rechargeable batteries for the field are outlined below (TEAM Network 2011b).

Rechargeable NiMH battery preparation

  1. If charging the batteries for the first time, or the first time for a given field season, put them in a discharging-recharging cycle (conditioning cycle) at least 48 hours before leaving for the field. This ensures that the battery “memory” is properly set and prolongs the life of the rechargeable battery. Refer to the battery charger for instructions to put the batteries into a condition cycle. Only use battery chargers that have this specification. Depending on the number of camera traps you have, multiple large battery chargers may be required to be used in parallel to prepare for the field.

  2. If not charging the batteries for the first time, discharge them first and recharge them for at least 24 hours before leaving for the field survey.

  3. Once the batteries are finished charging, check they have adequate voltage using a voltmeter. Rechargeable batteries will show a lower voltage than their posted voltage of 1.5 V, but this is normal for these battery types (between 1.25 and 1.3 V).

  4. Try not to charge the batteries more than 2–3 days before taking them into the field.

  5. Within 1–2 days of the field survey, insert the charged batteries into each camera trap so they are ready for the survey.

  6. Do not use the rechargeable batteries prepared for the field survey to configure the camera trap settings (see below). Use a spare set of batteries.

Desiccant

  1. If the camera traps are being deployed in humid or wet conditions, place a packet of desiccant (silica gel) inside each camera trap housing to help protect the electronics from moisture.

Additional guidelines

  • Obtain a background source image. This will typically be a Landsat satellite image and should be the most recent date freely available. Satellite imagery will be the first building block in determining the extent of spatially appropriate areas to deploy camera traps in an array.

  • Identify major access routes. These should include a good quality road or track along which a vehicle can travel into or through the project area (see Figure 7B). Create a buffer of at least 100 m to avoid camera trap points being placed within this designated proximity of a major access routes and/or roads.

  • Identify minor access routes. These can include any walking trail systems or old landholder tracks within the project area, specifically adjacent or located along the major access routes identified above. Create a buffer of at least 100 m to avoid camera trap points being placed within this designated proximity to existing minor access routes and/or trail systems.

  • When generating a camera trap array, consider the need to minimise disturbance of the project area associated with accessing each camera trap point. Identify existing tracks and trails, as well as passages that may be suitable for temporary access routes. Consider if temporary access routes are required to undertake other modules and if these can be combined with camera trap array temporary access routes.

  • Verify that the camera trap arrays will be accessible during the entire proposed deployment period (e.g. a property owner might close off a paddock/s for stocking reasons, limiting access).

  • Identify impenetrable areas.

  • Overlay a land cover/vegetation map. It is helpful to be aware of a general distribution of vegetation types and these can be delineated from a vegetation mapping spatial dataset, a land cover map or satellite image and/or with local expertise.

  • Depending on the target fauna and habitat within the project area, you may wish to define a smaller study area within the project area, which is all that is needed to satisfy the objectives of your survey.

  • Depending on the target fauna and habitat within the project area, you may wish to stratify the study area and generate camera arrays within specific habitat areas.

  • Overlay topographic data. For the majority of project areas, the most readily available product will be a coarse SRTM-derived Digital Elevation Model (DEM) with a spatial resolution of 90 m. These data will provide an idea of significant changes in elevation. For some project areas, local topography maps may have been digitized or generated from other sources and may be available for the analysis.

  • Determine if there is an elevation gradient. Analyse the DEM to ascertain if there are any significant elevation gradients evident (i.e. a difference of >1000 m between lowest and highest elevations within the project area or study area.

  • If there is a major altitudinal gradient within the project area or study area, you may consider generating multiple camera trapping grids or transects along this gradient (e.g. in three strata: low elevation, mid elevation and high elevation).

  • Identify rocky outcroppings by interpreting a satellite image. These areas may be digitised and then clipped out of the extent of the project area or study area before the camera trap array is generated.

  • Identify steep slopes that would prohibit traversing or sampling. To identify the slopes, derive a slope map from a DEM. Areas that are >45 degrees are masked out. Use this mask layer to omit those areas from the project area or study area.

  • Identify seasonally inundated areas, big ponds, or streams that may be impassable during the proposed deployment period. If these areas are easily identifiable, they can be digitised directly from an up-to-date satellite image. It should be noted that identifying inundated areas, especially seasonally inundated areas, can be very difficult and that consulting an expert with local knowledge of the area is highly recommended.

  • Identify open areas, or large gaps that are unsuitable for sampling. These may be digitised directly from an up-to-date satellite image also or from assistance of local expert who has knowledge of the area. Also, it should be noted that some gaps, for example, may represent senescent vegetation and not gaps.

  • The broad-scale camera trap points uploaded into the App are merely a navigational guide to arrive within the general vicinity of the computer-generated camera trap points. It is required that an updated location (being the actual location of the camera trap point at the time of deployment) be collected by marking a new waypoint within reasonable proximity to the original proposed point (TEAM Network 2011a).

Post-field survey tasks

Data upload, curation and submission

  • Once the mobile device has a data connection (i.e. WIFI or cellular), upload (by an explicit user action) all survey data on the App, including the project administration and camera trap survey metadata, to the staging database server for storage and curation.

  • When back in the office, manually upload the image and/or video data using the extract, transform and load (ETL) import facility for these data items, which parses image and video data files and uploads them to the staging database. You will be prompted to select the relevant project number and enter the camera trap number and SD card number to tag the images and/or video files.

  • Alongside the staging database server is a relational database server and associated production database. This database is the ‘end-point’ of each survey upload and it houses the ‘final’ data products from all modules completed during that survey. A periodic ingestion script converts staged project administration data, camera trap survey metadata and image/video data into the production relational database that is populated with a set of data and lookup tables.

  • Data curation is undertaken via the web-based view onto the production database and involves general checks and data cleaning (e.g. of free-text comments). The web-interface allows data to be viewed, for certain fields to be edited directly and provides search and retrieval functions for simple data extraction.

  • Use the web-based view onto the production database to link the project administration data and camera trap survey metadata to the image and/or video data via the project number, camera trap number and SD card number.

  • When the data from the survey has been curated, it can be marked as ‘Ready to publish’.

Image and video processing and tagging

  • Tag each individual image and/or video clip with a Media ID and Processing date.

  • If the image data includes bursts of images, tag each sequence of images with a Sequence group ID.

  • Tag each individual image and/or video clip with the Subject of the media (e.g. Survey start, Survey end, Surveyor, Animal, Unidentifiable, Unknown, Null, Time lapse).

  • Images and/or video with fauna need to be tagged with the Species name, Common name, Number of individuals, Identifier, Identification date (update from processing date if necessary), Identification confidence (i.e. certain, uncertain), Identification method (e.g. AI, expert, citizen scientist), and Identification comments (e.g. based on distribution, coat pattern, tail length).

  • Tag images and/or video without fauna (i.e. captured by false triggers) as ‘Null’.

Additional guidelines

The following points are adapted from Gillespie et al. (2015) and Molloy (2018).

  • Camera traps can collect large volumes of image and/or video data, particularly when arrays of cameras are deployed for weeks or months. Careful management and storage of data is needed to link media data to the corresponding camera trap and associated deployment metadata, and facilitate interpretation and data analyses. If possible, program the camera so that camera trap point name is added as a label to each image

  • Images and/or video should not be deleted from an SD card until it has been checked that they have been downloaded successfully.

  • It is good practice to keep a back-up copy of photos (i.e. on an external hard-drive) until processing has occurred.

  • Once all data is downloaded and checked, a good practice is to clear all SD cards, preferably by formatting. This ensures that SD cards are working correctly and prevents full cards from being reloaded into camera traps in future deployments.

  • Processing the images and/or video collected from camera traps can be time consuming. Ensure that sufficient time has been factored into project timelines for data processing.

  • It will be difficult to positively identify some species, especially from poor-quality images.

  • Familiarise yourself with the appearance, habitat and behaviour of the fauna that you are likely to encounter during your deployment.

  • In some cases, individual recognition of animals will be possible (i.e. those with distinct markings), but for most species it will only be possible to identify to the species rather than individual level.

  • Interpretation of camera trapping data requires that statistical analysis methods are applied to account for features of the data, in particular the likely presence of false negative occurrence records (i.e. species present in the project area but not detected).

  • See Molloy (2018) for tips for processing large amounts of camera trap data manually.
